meanings.definition: To lower in value or quality.
meanings.sent1: She tried to imbase the price of the old book.
meanings.sent2: It is not wise to imbase the reputation of others.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous elf decided to imbase the taste of the soup by adding too much salt.
meanings.sent4: The dark clouds seemed to imbase the beauty of the sunset.
meanings.sent5: The careless mistake could imbase the entire project.

meanings.sent1: He didn't want to imbase himself by lying about his achievements.
meanings.sent2: The villain's actions only served to imbase his character further.
meanings.sent3: The naughty puppy seemed determined to imbase the cleanliness of the freshly washed floor.
meanings.sent4: The graffiti on the historic building seemed to imbase its grandeur.
meanings.sent5: The rude comments were meant to imbase her self-esteem.

meanings.sent1: The company's decision to imbase the natural habitat was met with strong opposition.
meanings.sent2: Power has the potential to imbase even the most noble intentions.
meanings.sent3: The prankster thought it would be funny to imbase the clear water with food coloring.
meanings.sent4: The toxic fumes began to imbase the air we breathe.
meanings.sent5: The malicious software could imbase the security of the entire network.
